Award.AwardTitle: RET Site: Research Experiences for Teachers in Computer Vision and Bio-Medical Imaging

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This funding establishes a new Research Experience for Teachers (RET) Site at the University of Central Florida (UCF). The primary objective of this RET site is to engage high school teachers in summer research experiences in computer vision and bio-medical engineering. The teachers will develop classroom modules and materials which will be implemented in their classrooms during the academic year. The UCF RET team has an outstanding track record of achievements in computer vision research, education, outreach, and K-12 educational initiatives, including hosting the longest continually active CISE Research Experiences for Undergraduates Site. The team plans to provide research and professional development opportunities to high school teachers from the greater Orlando area. They particularly focus on teachers teaching Pre-Calculus, AP Calculus, AP Computer Science, AP Statistics, AP Physics, and AP or IB Biology, and the teachers interested in promoting Science Fair activities in their schools. The project will develop a community of teachers who are passionate about computer vision and imaging and who can translated this excitement to their students through engaging, high-quality inquiry learning experiences.

The project is anchored by a research area this is compelling and exciting for teachers and K-12 students and by an exceptional faculty team that has demonstrated expertise in both research and K-12 outreach. The site features projects that are teacher accessible as well as connected to current research and practice. The RET site includes sound evaluation and dissemination plans that may provide models for integrating computing and computer vision fundamentals and research into advanced high school subjects, filling an important disciplinary gap. The project will provide professional development to teachers from a local metropolitan region. Teachers will develop and hone their research, communication, and presentation skills, all of which are essential to their professional growth and success. The project will build the technical capacity of teachers so they are capable of developing and implementing new, exciting inquiry-based learning activities at their schools. The project team will disseminate the project materials through the TeachEngineering digital library and build a local Curriculum Web that will be shared with a wider audience of teachers and annual workshops. The team will also disseminate project results through high-quality journals and professional meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this RET project, covering the period from January 1, 2016 thru December 31, 2019, 30 teachers from several districts surrounding and including the Orlando area, spent a complete summer immersed in the Center for Research in Computer Vision (CRCV) at the University of Central Florida (UCF). Teachers were going to be teaching one of the AP STEM classes in the Fall, and the goal was to get involved in research in the Summer and to report on that research in the AP classroom in the following Fall and Spring. The AP areas that were included in the project were AP Calculus, AP Computer Science, AP Statistics, AP Biology and AP Physics. Additionally, teachers of IB Biology, Honors Biotech, and Honors Cybersecurity were included.

Each teacher focused on a topic that was central to the classroom curriculum and had an application to a topic in computer vision; thus, the research issues considered were those arising in computer vision. The teacher was paired with a Ph.D. student whose research the teacher spent much of the summer understanding and then took small steps towards further inquiry. A substantial component of the work was to translate the research project into classroom discourse, so that the high school student would understand what research questions the teacher had become familiar with, and what research questions were being investigated by researchers in CRCV and other relevant US institutions. Thus, the teacher played an ambassadorial role between interested high-school students and researchers at UCF's CRCV. The teacher also became a promoter of research and advanced educational pursuits in the milieu of secondary education.

Each year's cohort presented their experiences at a Dissemination Workshop to other middle and high school STEM teachers. Several teachers wrote and submitted presentations about their experience to educational publishing venues. Some notable accepted presentations are: 1) Ana Gonzalez, The Revolution of Artificial Intelligence in the AP Calculus Classroom, presented to the Florida Council of Teachers of Mathematics 2019, Jacksonville, FL; and the presentation was accepted to National Council of Teachers of  Mathematics 2020, Chicago, IL (accepted for presentation, but cancelled due to the pandemic). 2) Dana Singer, William Furiosi, Sharing Algorithmic Thinking in the AP Classroom, accepted to the AP Annual Conference 2020, Boston, MA (accepted for presentation, but cancelled due to the pandemic).
